4 Testing

Pyret’s definition forms—data-expr and fun-expr—both support where: blocks intended to hold tests for the definition. In addition, top-level check: blocks can hold tests. These blocks are handled specially when the program is run in check mode, which is the default mode for running Pyret programs.

4.1 Check Mode Desugaring

When running in check mode, Pyret scans the statements of each block in the program for check: blocks and definitions with attached where: blocks. It collects these blocks and sets them up to be run at the end of the block it finds them in, so they are run after all functions and data definitions have already been defined.

This happens to all inner blocks as we,, so check: and where: blocks in nested scopes (say for helper functions) are run each time the function is called.

So, for example, in this program, 14 tests are run. The comments show how that number accumulates:

fun exp(x :: Number, y :: Number):

  when y < 0:

    raise("Cannot take negative exponents")

  end

  if y == 0:

    1

  else:

    fun times-x(n :: Number0):

      x * n

    where:

      times-x(4) is (4 * x)

      timex-x(10) is (10 * x)

    end

    times-x(exp(x, y - 1))

  end

where:

  exp(3, 2) is 9  # inside exp, the else: block is evaluated twice,

                  # so there are 2 invocations of times-x's tests,

                  # and 4 successes

                  # Including this test, after this line, 5 tests

                  # have passed (0 + 5)

 

  exp(4, 3) is 64 # inside exp, the else: block is evaluated three times,

                  # so there are 3 invocations of times-x,

                  # and 6 successes.

                  # Including this test, after this line, 12 tests

                  # have passed (5 + 7)

 

  exp(5, 0) is 1  # inside exp, the else: block is not evaluated,

                  # so the times-x where: block is not run

                  # Including this test, after this line, 13 tests

                  # have been run (12 + 1)

 

  exp(3, -1) raises "Cannot take negative exponents"

                  # inside exp, the else: block is not evaluated,

                  # so the times-x where: block is not run

                  # Including this test, after this line, 14 tests

                  # have been run (13 + 1)

end

4.2 Check Mode Helpers

There are two syntactic forms that are helpful for testing programs inside check: and where: blocks.

is

The is form accepts two expressions on either side of the is operator:

expr "is" expr

This first evaluates the left expression, and then the right. If either signals an exception, the whole is test fails with that exception as the reason. If both expressions evaluate to values, they are compared for equality. If the equality check succeeds, the test is registered as a success, otherwise it fails with a message about the two values not being equal.

Under the hood, the is form is calling the built-in library function checkers.check-is [REF].

raises

The raises form accepts two expressions on either side of the raises operator:

expr "raises" expr

This first evaluates the expression on the right and expects it to be a string. It then evaluates the expression on the left. If the left expression completes without error, the test fails with a message indicating that an exception was expected and none occurred. If the left expression signals an exception, the exceptions value is compared against the provided string as follows:

  • If the exception value is a string, raises checks for containment of the provided test string in the exception value.

  • If the exception value is an error object, raises checks for containment of the provided test string in the message field of the exception value.
